Ama works to support her husband financially to provide for the family. She is a trader. She trades in foodstuffs such as cassava flour. She procures the goods from nearby communities and sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers. Ama also treks to get supplies.

She has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her child the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs.

loans.name: Asociacion De Cristo #5-8 Group

texts.en:
Lucia, 40, is a borrower who lives near San Pedro D. Macorís, Dominican Republic. Lucia is the coordinator for her group, Asociacion D. Cristo (Association of Christ), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group. Lucia and the other women in Asociacion D. Cristo live in Boca Chica, a town between San Pedro and Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic. Boca Chica is known for tourism and visits to the beach, and Lucia has taken advantage of that trend by running a business selling bathing suits. She will use this loan to buy the bathing suits at wholesale prices, and then sell them at a small markup. Lucia has seven children. She lives at home with her husband and four of her children, and it can be a crowded place. She hopes to make additions to her home so that there is more room, and she also hopes to one day own the building where she runs her business.

Lucia has successfully repaid four loans with Esperanza International, and she is excited to be taking out her fifth. Lucia said that she and her family “have overcome everything to get to where [they] are”. She is very thankful for Esperanza, not just for its loans but also for its “lower rates, savings, and the clinics” that are provided to all associates. Thank you for lending to Lucia and the Asociacion D. Cristo group!

loans.use: To purchase men's and women's bathing suits

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim S., 45, is married with three young children living at home in the Takeo province. 

She works in a grocery store, typically making $8 USD each day. Her husband stays at home and helps her. Kim S. would like a loan of $1,000 USD to expand her grocery inventory.

loans.use: To expand her grocery inventory.

loans.name: Tauavae

texts.en:
Tauavae is 29 and married with 3 children (ages 6-month - 6 years old).  She owns & operates a business venture, selling fried foods in the local community.  She has 2 years of experience in this business.    Tauavae  needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase raw ingredients needed to make pancakes and german buns for sA..  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 350 talas or US $146 per week) to pay for her children's tuition fees.

In 2008, Tauavae  joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Tauavae 's 2nd loan with SPBD. 

In addition, SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a "3 out of 3" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a "2 out of 3" = secondary/high-school, and a "1 out of 3" would mean that the borrower is uneducated. 

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

Tauavae's Overall Social Metric Score:*               1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2.3 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.8 out of 3

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD:
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make pancakes and german buns for sale

loans.name: Ayurzana

texts.en: Ayurzana N. is 39 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Uvs province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. He has two daughters and two sons, of whom the oldest three children go to local secondary schools. Ayurzana owns a small car that he uses as a taxi in the town. He has been working as a taxi driver since 2007. Since there is almost no public transportation in the town, taxis are quite in demand and he is an experienced taxi driver. Due to health issues, he went to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia for hospital treatment and got back after seven months of treatment. Since then, he has been working hard and recently he sold his old car for profit and bought a bigger car in order to serve his customers better. He requests a loan to get his car serviced and to change the tires for better ones.

loans.use: To get his taxi serviced and purchase new tires

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy an additional taxi

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam C. is married and a small business person. She has been in the business for three years. Mariam runs a business selling both used and new clothes at Tungi Awr in Dar es Salaam. She purchases her goods from Karume, small business city market center for used goods and from the Kariakoo wholesale shopping center. Business income generated from the business is used to meet her daily family needs and to expand the business. 

Mariam is requesting a loan of T.shs. 500,000 to buy more business goods. .

loans.use: To buy more new and used clothing for resale

loans.name: Leandra

texts.es:
La señora Leandra es socia del Banco Comunal “Dios es Amor” desde hace 8 años, vive en el distrito de Juliaca, provincia de San Román y departamento de Puno, tiene 44 años de edad, es casada y tiene 05 hijos. Ella estudió hasta quinto de primaria, se dedica a la compra y venta de fibra de animales.

Leandra nos cuenta que el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, lo que le sirvió para aumentar su capital.

Ella solicitará un crédito  de S/. 2,000.00 nuevos soles, con el cual podrá comprar  fibra de alpaca, vicuña, ovino, etc.

Su sueño para el futuro es aumentar su negocio y sus ganancias. 

Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal son los ahorros y las facilidades de préstamo.
texts.en:
Sra. Leandra has been a member of the Communal Bank “Dios es Amor” (God is Love) for the past eight years. She lives in the District of Juliaca, San Román Province, Deparment of Puno. Leandra is 44 years old, married, and has five children. She has a fifth grade education and makes a living by buying and selling animal wool.

Leandra says the first loan she requested from Manuela Ramos was in the amount of 300 soles and used to increase her capital. She is now requesting a loan of 2000 soles to buy the wool of alpacas, vicuñas, sheep, and other animals. Her dream is to increase her business and earnings. What she enjoys most about her Communal Bank are the savings accounts and the simplicity of the loans.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase animal wool

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe L. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old. Fe is married and has four school-age children. To make a living, Fe owns a specialized retail store which primarily sells seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Fe has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Fe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Fe is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Fe from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita is 36 years old and married with three children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home. She has a good relationship with LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization). LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She is a friendly and honest woman. She sells drinks at retail prices. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Josinta

texts.en:
Josinta R. is the twenty-eight-year-old mother of two children who is married to Joasiah Imbali, a painter. Their two children, James and Lin, are in a local primary school.

Josinta runs a stall, selling groceries, cereals and clothing in Manyatta estate, a low income settlement estate in Kisumu City. Her stall is located near a pathway and thus is easily accessible to many, especially women who come to buy fruit and vegetables for their families. Josinta has been running this business for the last ten years.

A friend introduced Josinta to KADET and she is currently taking her second loan, after successfully repaying a first loan without difficulties. She plans to purchase more cereals for sale and use part of the money to venture into a wholesale stocking of household items (locally known as mali mali). 

Josinta’s hope is to one day open a permanent and spacious stall for clothes, separate from cereals and vegetables. Josinta, a self-motivated woman, wants to educate her children and later buy a plot of land and build a residential home.

loans.use: To buy more cereals to sell

loans.name: Andrea

texts.en:
Andrea is an individual loan client with Esperanza. Her story is representative Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally, many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. She is located in the rural areas surrounding El Seybo, an area economically based around agriculture, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and their four children.

Andrea is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza, and her second individual loan after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothing by purchasing two dozen pairs of shoes, a dozen pairs of pants, skirts and blouses in the capital in the main markets and then selling them in her community at a profit. She will use the profits to construct her own home and "to get out of poverty!" She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy two dozen pairs of shoes, a dozen pairs of pants, skirts and blouses for resale

loans.name: Bakary

texts.fr:
Monsieur Bakary Diakité est un homme marié de 44 ans et père de 5 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants à Dangassa, un village de la commune rurale de Ouelessebougou.
Il a vite abandonné l’école coranique pour s’intéresser aux  activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat et à la vente de céréales auprès de son père.  Avec plus de 10 ans d’expériences, Monsieur Bakary Diakité maîtrise son activité.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, il décide de collaborer avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son premier prêt individuel et compte l’utiliser pour acheter, des sacs de céréales auprès des producteurs  à Dangassa et  environs. Il effectue sa vente  à Bamako,  Dangassa et à Sanankoroba à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice il envisage agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Bakary Diakité is married, 44 years old, and the father of five children. He lives with his wife and children in Dangassa, a village in the rural area of Ouelessebougou. He quickly left Koranic school to pursue his interest in business, specifically the buying and selling of grain, which he did alongside his father. With more than ten years of experience, Mr. Bakary Diakité has mastered his trade. In his research of supplemental financial resources, he has decided to collaborate with the loan program at the microfinance institution of Soro Yiriwaso. This is his first individual loan and intends to use it to buy bags of grain from producers in Dangassa and its surrounding areas. He does his selling in Bamako, Dangassa and Sanankoroba to a clientele made up of men and women. With this loan, he intends to earn a monthly profit of 50,000 FCFA. With this profit he plans to expand his business.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grain

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma is a single mother of three children and all her children go to school. Fatuma doesn’t take care of additional family members.  She owns a stall in Owino selling second hand clothes and sells to all categories of people.  Fatuma has been in this business for six years, selling at retail and wholesale. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes.  Fatuma doesn’t have any side business. She uses public transport to and from home to her place of work in Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. Fatuma buys from the very market where she works.  She works seven days a week. Her business challenges include seasonality and thieves.  She aspires to see her business grow big and start selling at wholesale only. Fatuma decided to work with MCDT because she wanted to get more money for her business.  She resides in and owns a three-roomed house where she stays with eight people and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more second hand clothes

loans.name: Halimatou Abibou

texts.fr: Halimatou Abibou D. est une femme de 51 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 10 enfants et tutrice de 03 autres garçons confiés par des parents. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de SINTHIANG COUNDARA dont elle est la présidente depuis son inauguration le 22 janvier 2003. Elle est restauratrice ; tous les mardis, jour de marché hebdomadaire, elle y va pour vendre son repas. Elle est également détentrice de boutique dans le village, elle y vend divers produit tels du riz, de l’huile, du sucre, des biscuits, etc. son objectif d’une part,  est de participer à la prise en charge de la famille par exemple la santé, la nourriture et la scolarité, d’autre part, augmenter son niveau d’épargne.
texts.en:
Halimatou Abibou D., 51, is married and the mother of 10 children as well as being the guardian of three other boys entrusted to her by their parents. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of SINTHIANG COUNDARA of which she is the president, since its inception on January 22, 2003. She sells cooked food; every Tuesday, the weekly marketday, she goes to the market to sell her meals. She also has a little store in the village where she sells such products as rice, oil, sugar, biscuits, etc. One of her goals is to participate in supporting the family, for example in covering healthcare, food, and school fees, and a second is to add to her savings.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: expanding her income-generating activities

loans.name: Julio Crispin

texts.es: Julio es de 33 años de edad, tiene tres hijas, se dedica a la actividad de carpintería hace mas de 10 años, lo cual le ha  ayudado al sustento de su familia. En ASDIR solicita su primer préstamo para incrementar su capital de trabajo en materia prima, sus referencias apersónales indican que es una persona responsable con mucho ánimo de superar.
texts.en:
Julio is 33 years old and has three daughters. He has worked as a carpenter for more than 10 years, which has helped him provide for his family. He is applying for his first loan with ASDIR to increase his business capital with raw materials. His personal references indicate that he is a responsible person with a real desire to overcome his problems.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials for furniture making

loans.name: Maureen

texts.en: Maureen H. is from the village of Seaside, Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 40 years old and is married with five school-aged children. Maureen owns and operates a business selling personal home products as a dealer of branded products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Maureen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Florencio

texts.en:
Florencio S. is from the village of Solinog Calamba Misamis Occidental. He is 55 years old. Florencio is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Florencio owns and operates a business providing passenger services in a "motorcab" to local community members. Florencio has been engaged in his business for more than ten years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Florencio joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Florencio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide services. Florencio is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Florencio from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita A. is from the town of Talibon. She is 45 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Angelita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. 

Angelita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees and supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anara's Group

texts.en:
Anara B. is the leader of this group.  She is 47 and a widow. She has two sons and a daughter. The sons went away to work in Russia and the daughter is preschool age (under 7).  In order to make money Anara breeds farm animals. She has been doing it for sixteen years.  Every month she sells some animals in order to make money to cover family expenses. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future Anara plans to repair her house and improve their living conditions. 

Zhyldyz A., 44, is married.  She has four daughters; three of them are married and live separately with their families and the youngest daughter is at school. Zhyldyz works as a secretary and her husband is a pensioner. Eleven years ago with the initial investment of 6000 soms her husband purchased sheep and since that moment Zhyldyz and her husband have been breeding livestock.  Every month they sell some sheep to cover family expenses.  Zhyldyz applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase more sheep to increase the number of livestock.  In the future she wants to repair the shed.
 
Gulgaaky J., 35, is a widow. She has two daughters; both of them are at school. Two years ago her parents gave her two sheep as a present. And then Gulgaaky started to breed livestock. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase more sheep in order to increase the number of livestock.  In the future she wants to purchase a house.

Aizat A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 22 and works as an inspector in the Social Department.  With money received from the loan she wants to improve her living conditions and purchase a fridge. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Las Progresistas De Cupiche Group

texts.es:
Alcancia Comunal “Las Progresistas de Cupiche” este conforman ocho integrantes dedicados al comercio y al servicio de lavandería del transporte interprovincial, 

Ynes Gladis C. con 39 años, es la tesorera de esta Alcancía Comunal . casada, con dos hijos dependientes, Ynes de dedica al servicio de lavandería de carros interprovinciales que llegan de distintos lugares del interior de Perú (Huánuco; Pasco, Huancayo, Pucallpa, Tingo Maria, etc), lleva 10 años haciendo este servicio; asimismo hace tres años, se dedica a realizar y elaborar tejido artesanal a palitos y crochett,  como medias, ponchos, chompas, etc,  ofreciendo estas prendas al por mayor y menor; se animó a elaborar estos tejidos, con las intenciones de poder colaborar con su esposo, quien trabaja realizando servicios de transporte, con un carrito alquilado que ha diario le da para los gastos del día pero no lo suficiente,  asi ambos aportan en su hogar para mejorar su economía. Las ganancias que ella obtiene, las invierte 
en los estudios de sus dos hijos, uno de ellos lleva preparándose para postular a la Universidad.
 Esta familia anhela mucho adquirir una movilidad propia que le ayude a mejorar su ingresos económicos, además comprar una maquina de cocer, lanas, hilos, agujas, o otros materiales que le son útiles para su trabajo, la Alcancia Comunal “Las Progresistas de Cupiche”, están agradecidos por el préstamo otorgado y aseguran pagar sus cuotas puntualmente.
texts.en:
The “Las Progresistas de Cupiche” communal bank has 8 members; some are merchants and others provide a car wash service for interprovincial buses. Ynes Gladis C., 39, is group Treasurer. She’s married and has two dependent children. She provides a car wash service for interprovincial cars that arrive from various points in the Peruvian interior (Huánuco, Pasco, Huancayo, Pucallpa, Tingo Maria, etc.). She has been providing this service for 10 years. Three years ago she started to make artisanal knitting and crochet works like socks, ponchos, sweaters, etc. that she sells at wholesale and retail. She was motivated to go into crafts with the intention of helping her husband, who works in transport with a leased car and barely earns enough for daily expenses, so that both of them could contribute to improving their family income. Thanks to her earnings they can pay for their two children’s education; one of them is getting ready to seek admission to the University. This family very much wants to acquire a vehicle of their own that will help them improve income in addition to buying a sewing machine, wools, threads, needles and other materials that are useful for her work. The members of the “Las Progresistas de Cupiche” communal bank are grateful for the loan granted and assure its prompt repayment.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine, wools, threads, needles and other materials.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita C. is a widow  who lives in Prk. Paho, Brgy. Pacol, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: vegetable farming, rice farming and RTW (ready-to-wear) businesses. Teresita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired to something better for her family. 

With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Teresita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 12,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 13th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000, which she intends to use to buy fertilizers, pesticides and insecticides for her farming activities so that she can continue to save up for her children's future education. Teresita C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'Honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides and insecticides

loans.name: Damiana

texts.en:
Damiana A. is from the village of Calamagui. She is 49 years old, married and has nine school-aged children. To make a living, Damiana owns and operates a business venture providing manicure and pedicure services to local community members. Damiana has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 5,200 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2007, Damiana joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide services. Damiana is requesting a new loan of 27,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase materials needed to provide services. This loan will be her seventh from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide services

loans.name: German

texts.es:
El señor German  vive en casa propia en la zona de Tacagua de la ciudad de La Paz, esta casado y todos sus hijos ya son mayores de edad; la actividad que realiza es la confección de chompas de lana en un pequeño taller que instaló en su domicilio en el cual trabaja con su esposa.

El crédito que solicita es para comprar material (lana) y poder mantener su negocio estable.

Es cliente antiguo y paga muy bien por lo tanto puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
German lives in his own home in the Tacagua neighborhood in the city of La Paz.  He is married and all of his children are grown.  

He works making wool sweaters in a small workshop located in his home.  His wife works there too.

He is asking for this loan to purchase material (wool) and to keep his business stable.

He is an old customer and pays on time, so he is eligible for a new loan.

loans.use: Purchase wool for his sweater making business

loans.name: Josefina Hortencia

texts.es: Josefina Hortenciab T. G.,es una señora casada, tiene 30 años de edad, tiene un hijo, ella es de oficios Secretaria Bilingue con Orientación en computación, actualmente se desempeña como profesional en un colegio, ubicado en este mucicipio y departamento, donde devenga un ingreso que es suficiente para sostener a su familia, por motivos personales tiene que hacer una gasto, por lo que se presentó a ASDIR, para solicitar un prestamo que le servirá para realizar un evento festivo, con el plan de pagos que se le hace acepta la misma, sabiendo que es parte de su desarrollo familiar, como también social.
texts.en:
Josefina Hortencia T. G., 30, is married and has a son.  She is employed as a Bilingual Secretary with an emphasis in Computer Skills at a local high school, located in this municipality and department, where she earns a monthly salary sufficient to support her family.

She has a personal expenditure due to personal reasons.  She came by ASDIR to request a loan that will make it possible for her to carry out a festive event.

She accepts the loan with its attendant payment plan cognizant that it is part of her family and social development.

loans.use: To pay for a festive event.

loans.name: Ilham

texts.en: Ilham H. is engaged in manufacturing and preparing orders working with iron. He has seven years of experience in this field. He is married and has two children. Ilham's son actively helps him in this business. Ilham has a lot of orders but he is not able financially to purchase sufficient iron to accept all orders and for this purpose he has applied for a loan of 1,500 AZN. Ilhan also would like to rent a bigger place to work. He promises to repay accurately and believes that this loan will increase his income and number of clients, which will allow him to improve his life and the lives of his children.

loans.use: To purchase more iron materials and rent a bigger place to work.

loans.name: Nancy Estamilda

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “LIDERANDO LAS PALMERAS”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Nancy Estamilda; ella tiene 46 años de edad y es casada y tiene 2 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de snack cafetería, ella trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 9.00 p.m, la socia por medio de este negocio saca adelante a sus hijos, la socia quiere ampliar y mejorar el negocio de snack cafetería. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar implementos para el snack. 

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Nancy Estamilda is a member of the “Liderando Las Palmeras” community bank which is located in Cusco district, in the province and department of the same name.

Nancy Estamilda is 46 years old.  She is married and has 2 children.  She divides her time between her daily activities and her snack bar / café business.  She works from 8.00am to 9.00pm.  Through this business she is getting her children ahead in life.  She would like to expand and improve her snack bar / café business.  She is requesting this loan to buy supplies for her snack bar.

Nancy Estamilda is grateful to those who will take part in her dream by funding her loan and she pledges to make her repayments in a timely manner.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her snack bar

loans.name: Aidé Esperanza

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal 3 de Mayo se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo. Lugar conocido por ser una zona muy comercial, por sus fiestas tradicionales de San Pedro y San Pablo y por la alegría de su gente.

La señora Aidé esta en el Banco comunal  hace 10 años y le gusta por los beneficios adicionales que brinda la institución y por las facilidades para los créditos. Tiene 33 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene 4 hijos de 13, 12,  9 y 4 años, los dos mayores estudian en colegio Y los menores en escuela y jardín de infantes. Su esposo es comerciante.

Ella es una ama de casa que realiza el crédito para el negocio de sus esposo el cual  se dedica al comercio, vende  controles remotos de televisores y otros artefactos eléctricos, carcasas y accesorios de teléfonos celulares, a esta labor se dedica todos los días desde las 8h00 hasta las 18h00. El recorre las calles de la ciudad ofreciendo sus productos, esta labor la viene realizando hace como 6 años en los que ha tenido momentos buenos y malos, pero que sabe llevar con duro trabajo. Sus productos los va a comprar en Guayaquil.

Este crédito es para comprar controles,  carcasas y accesorios para teléfono. Sus sueños son tener su casa de cemento ya que la que tiene es de caña.
texts.en:
The community bank 3 de Mayo [May 3], meets every two weeks in Picoaza parish in the city of Portoviejo, an area known for its shopping area, the traditional feasts of Saint Peter and Saint Paul, and the happiness of its people.

Aidé has been a member of the community bank for 10 years, and she likes the benefits it provides and that it makes it easy to apply for loans.  She is 33 years old, married, and has four children, who are 4, 9, 12, and 13 years old.  The two oldest are in high school and the younger ones are in primary school and pre-school.  Her husband is a merchant.

She is a housewife who is applying for this loan for her husband's business, which sells TV remotes, other electronics, cell phone casings, and other cell phone accessories.  He works at this business from 8:00am until 6:00pm.  He travels through the city streets offering his products.  He has been doing this work for six years, and he has had good and bad moments, but he knows how to work hard.  He goes to Guayaquil to purchase his products.

This loan will be used to purchase TV remotes, cell phone casings, and phone accessories.  Their dream is to have a cement house since the one they have now is made of cane.

loans.use: Purchase cell phone casings, cell phone accessories, and TV remotes

loans.name: Apolonio

texts.es: Apolonio I. M. desea empezar la construcción de una barda al frente de su casa y poner portón metálico para la protección de su familia, el terreno que compro hace años es muy grande para que cuando sus hijos crecieran construyeran ahí sus vivienda, por lo que el aun estén ya de edad adultos se preocupa por el bienestar de todos. Para poder realizar su proyecto el necesita comprar material de construcción y pagar la mano de obra.
texts.en: Apolonio I. M. wishes to start building a wall in front of his home and put in a metal gate to protect his family. The land he purchased years ago is very big, so when his children grew up they built homes there. Even though they are adults he still worries about everyone's well being. In order to carry out this project, he needs to purchase construction materials and pay for labor.

loans.use: Put up a wall and gate in front of his home

loans.name: Yarn

texts.en: Yarn S., 33, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. S. sells clothes, earning an income of USD 7 per day. Her husband is a driver, earning an income of USD 15 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 35 on food and USD 17 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more clothes to resell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Part of 31-year-old Chan V.’s daily routine is making baskets. She and her husband, who live in the province of Kompong Chhnang, buy raw materials to make baskets to sell around their community. They also buy baskets from other weavers at reasonable prices and resell them to gain extra profits. They have been doing this work since 2000. Chan V. is not comfortable because her house often needs to be repaired. Therefore, she would like a loan to buy some wood to repair her old house. Chan V. is the mother of one child.

loans.use: to buy some wood to repair her old house

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn S. is from the village of Bangahan, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 43 years old. Marlyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marlyn owns & operates a retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling health & medicinal products, like medicinal coffee, in the local community. She also sells blouses from NATASHA & AVON.  Marlyn has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Marlyn is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like multivitamins & food supplements. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Marlyn from HSPFI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell, like multivitamins & food supplements

loans.name: Roger

texts.en:
Roger L. is from the town of Plaridel. He is 34 years old and single. To make a living, Roger owns a business selling snacks and other delicacies. He has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Roger joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC, used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Roger is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Roger from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Maximo

texts.en:
Maximo is from the village of Banicapt Galas. He is 54 years old, separated, and has three adult-aged children. He operates a family member's business in the agriculture sector, primarily raising pigs in the backyard. He has been engaged in this business for one year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP per month.
In 2010, Maximo joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to purchase materials for the construction of a pig fence. Maximo is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase piglets and feed. This will be his third loan from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his family's general living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and feed for his piggery

loans.name: Maria Julieta

texts.es: Maria Julieta C. S.:de 36 años de edad es casada tiene 3 hijos los tres estan estudiando en una escuela publica,su negocio es de venta de ropa nueva lo inicio hace 4 años ella tiene un pequeño local a la orilla de la calle principal donde ella vive los vecinos ya la conocen y se asercan desde muy temprano para comprar su mercaderia el prestamo que ella solicita es para la compra de ropa nueva por mayor,su sueño es expandirse y abrir un nuevo local en el municipio de su localidad para poder obtener mejores ganancias y darles un mejor futuro a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Maria Julieta C. S., 36, is married and has three children who go to public school.  Her business is new clothes sales.  She started it four years ago and she has a small locale along the main street where she lives.  Neighbors know her and come by from early in the morning to buy merchandise.

The loan she’s asking for is to buy new clothes at wholesale.  Her dream is to expand and open a new locale in her local town to get better profits and provide a better future for her children.

loans.use: to buy new clothes at wholesale.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 49-year-old married man living with his wife and two young children. He is from Lebanon. He's owned his shop since 1983, selling music CDs and video tapes. In addition, he sells mobiles pre-paid cards. He struggles with lack of financial capital. So today, he is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase additional products. By doing this, he should be able to increase his income and overcome the difficulties in improving himself and strengthening his business.

loans.use: to purchase additional products.

loans.name: Zablon Mwangi

texts.en:
Zablom Mwangi, 28, is a single businessman who supports his parents, brothers and sisters. He has been running his motorcycle transport business for about two years with an income of 2,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) per month.

This is his first loan cycle with KADET after being introduced by a staff member. He wants to use it to buy a piece of land together with his group members. He hopes to improve his living standard and to be able to expand his transport services.

loans.use: to buy a piece of land as a group.
